on AISI 4130 steel in the surface hardening process was studied. To investigate the surface properties,
geometrical dimensions of the hardened zone, microhardness distribution in width and depth of LSTH,
percentage of the ferrite phase, and microstructure of the hardened surface were investigated.

represents the maximum intensity, while r
upper and the lower radius in the upper plane at z = z
and in the lower plane at z = z
The radius r is given by
In this study, the effects of Nd:YAG laser parameters (i.e., LSS, laser power, and stand-off
distance) on AISI 4130 steel in the surface hardening process was studied. To investigate the surface
properties, geometrical dimensions of the hardened zone, microhardness distribution in width and
depth of LSTH, percentage of the ferrite phase, and microstructure of the hardened surface were
The shape of the hardened zone was affected by the shape of the Gaussian laser energy
distribution, as shown in Figure 5. The Nd:YAG laser used in this study had a Gaussian mode in
which the maximum energy was focused at the middle of the laser beam. The laser energy reduced
aside the middle of the laser beam. By increasing the distance from the focal plane (see z in Figure 5),
not only the energy was reduced, but also the laser beam diverged.
Schematic of laser beam Gaussian distribution [35].
The input parameter effects on the hardened zone geometry are plotted in Figures 6–8. The focal
plane position had a direct effect on the width and a reverse effect on the depth and angle [37]. This
ects on the hardened zone geometry are plotted in Figures
plane position had a direct e
ect on the width and a reverse e
ect on the depth and angle [
This phenomenon can be explained by analysis of the laser beam distribution displayed in Figure
In fact, by increasing the focal plane position (z distance in Figure
], which caused a wider and shallower hardened layer. While the width
of the hardened layer increased and the depth decreased, the angle became smaller. Figure
account for the inﬂuence of LSS on the geometrical dimensions of the hardened layer. It consisted
in the fact that the lower LSS caused wider and deeper case hardening with a bigger layer angle.
That can be explained with LSS reduction, which increased the interaction time between the material
and the laser beam. Therefore, more heat energy was transferred to the surface of the samples and
wider and deeper hardened layers were achieved. Sample #9 had a deeper hardened layer, which was
mwidth. Although samples #2 and #3 had the maximumdepth and hardness, i.e.,
the surface of these samples was melted, they were not the best ones, while transformation hardening
was desired. The melting surface was due to lower focal plane position distance (8 mm and 9 mm),
which led to higher energy concentration and then the energy caused the melt of the material surface.
The pulse energy is calculated by Equations (3) and (4):
where E is the pulse energy (joule),
The inﬂuence of pulse widthonthe depth, width, andhardenedlayer angle is showninFigure
respectively. Increasing the pulse width led to increases in the depth and hardened layer angle. When
